messageBody:
Thank you for your help! I got some idea from you. Thanks.

But if the classes and the methods I want to test are abstract, I
can't know what will happen in the methods of the subclasses which
extend from these abstract classes. Why I asked this question is that
these classes I will test are a framework of our project, many of
them are abstract classes. Our project team must follow this
framework and extend from these abstract classes to develop our
project. Now I was assigned to test if this framework is correct.
What can I do?
Any help will be appreciated greatly!

--- In junit@y..., Rob Nielsen <rob@v...> wrote:
> If the method doesn't return anything then it probably modifies
fields
> of the class somehow. You can therefore test the value of this
changed
> object. ie:
>
> public class Foo
> {
> int x;
>
> public Foo(int x)
> {
> this.x=x;
> }
>
> public int getX()
> {
> return x;
> }
>
> public void incrementX()
> {
> x++;
> }
> }
>
> public class FooTest extends TestCase
> {
> public void testIncrementX()
> {
> Foo foo=new Foo(5);
> foo.incrementX();
> assertEquals(6,foo.getX());
> }
> }
>
> chenhuitao@y... wrote:
> >
> > I am a newbie to junit.But now i have a job in my hand.I need to
use
> > JUnit to test some existed java programme.Some methods of classes
> > have no return value.I can not change the source programme.How
can I
> > test these programme by JUnit?
> > Thank you for your any help!
> > //BR ChenHuitao
